repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: This PR implements the major perf gain of #26827 without adding the incremental invalidation part of that PR. The change is thus a lot smaller, hopefully making the logic easier to understand and review. The incremental invalidation doesn't really make a difference anyway, except for very large files that also have combined injections. But this can be handled down the road in another PR

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    local start_line, end_line ---@type integer, integer

    if full_scan then
      start_line, _, end_line = root_node:range()
    else
      start_line, _, end_line = Range.unpack4(range --[[@as Range]])
    end
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -986,18 +1001,28 @@ end
 --- TODO: Allow for an offset predicate to tailor the injection range
 ---       instead of using the entire nodes range.
 --- @private
+--- @param range Range|true
 --- @return table<string, Range6[][]>
-function LanguageTree:_get_injections()
+function LanguageTree:_get_injections(range)
   if not self._injection_query or #self._injection_query.captures == 0 then
+    self._processed_injection_range = entire_document_range
     return {}
   end
 
   ---@type table<integer,vim.treesitter.languagetree.Injection>
   local injections = {}
 
+  local full_scan = range == true or self._injection_query.has_combined_injections
+
   for index, tree in pairs(self._trees) do
     local root_node = tree:root()
-    local start_line, _, end_line, _ = root_node:range()
+    local start_line, end_line, _ ---@type integer, integer, integer
+
+    if full_scan then
+      start_line, _, end_line, _ = root_node:range()
+    else
+      start_line, _, end_line, _ = Range.unpack4(range --[[@as Range]])
+    end

comment_data.body:
This is getting off-topic, but maybe a tracking issue would be useful? With a table comparing what luacheck, stylua, luals, and emmyluals provide so we _know_ what we're talking about and can make a decision with confidence?

We could then switch to only enabling the warnings we really care about (and are not better covered by stylua and luals -- which unfortunately is much slower) instead of drinking from the firehose (i.e., use `only` instead of `ignore`).

(Here's the luacheck list, for future reference: https://luacheck.readthedocs.io/en/stable/warnings.html)

comment_data.body: FWIW I don't think Luacheck has any useful checks that aren't already done by LuaLS.

comment_data.body:
Yes, but it would be good to explicitly document that. There's not too many checks; the `6xx` are clearly covered by stylua, the `0xx` are about luacheck itself; and the handful of others that we don't already ignore could be either ticked off against luals diagnostics or argued to be irrelevant for us. (At a glance, only the `5xx` are of potential interest. Empty blocks for example are luacheck-only from a brief test, for example.)

(This is not about adding friction but about having something written down we can refer to when the next generation of maintainers discovers luacheck and goes "why aren't we using that?!")

+    end

comment_data.body:
These are the checks I think aren't covered from LuaLS and Stylua:

```
111 Setting an undefined global variable. -- LuaLS only checks global variables must be uppercase, so mostly equiv
541 An empty do end block. -- probably a LuaLS bug since it checks empty loop/if statements
512 Loop can be executed at most once. -- not that useful
314 Value of a field in a table literal is unused. -- sounds useful
561 Cyclomatic complexity of a function is too high. -- huh?
581 Negation of a relational operator- operator can be flipped. -- sounds useful
582 Error prone negation: negation has a higher priority than equality. -- sounds useful
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -986,18 +1001,28 @@ end
 --- TODO: Allow for an offset predicate to tailor the injection range
 ---       instead of using the entire nodes range.
 --- @private

-function LanguageTree:_get_injections()

   if not self._injection_query or #self._injection_query.captures == 0 then
+    self._processed_injection_range = entire_document_range
     return {}
   end
 
   ---@type table<integer,vim.treesitter.languagetree.Injection>
   local injections = {}
 
+  local full_scan = range == true or self._injection_query.has_combined_injections
+
   for index, tree in pairs(self._trees) do
     local root_node = tree:root()
-    local start_line, _, end_line, _ = root_node:range()
+    local start_line, end_line, _ ---@type integer, integer, integer

+    if full_scan then
+      start_line, _, end_line, _ = root_node:range()
+    else
+      start_line, _, end_line, _ = Range.unpack4(range --[[@as Range]])
+    end

comment_data.body:
We ignore `581` since it's not true when tables are involved. (And, yes, `561` is a weird one. I don't think we even enable the ~chromatic~ cyclomatic check.)

Assuming that `541` can get fixed (not a big loss in the meantime), this only leaves `582` and potentially `314`. The former sounds also prone to false positives, and the latter would be something that could be proposed to luals/emmyluals?

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: perf(treesitter): only search for injections within the parse range
